G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable to modifications of custody and parenting time), and pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, as this Court entered the original custody and parenting-time judgment on April 15, 2019.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable to modifications of custody and parenting time), and pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, as this Court entered the original custody and parenting-time judgment on April 15, 2019.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20 (as applicable to modifications of custody and parenting time), and pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, as this Court entered the original custody and parenting-time judgment on April 15, 2019.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because it is the court that issued the existing custody and parenting‑time order, and because the minor child resides within the jurisdiction of this Court. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 223, § 1.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Barnstable Probate and Family Court because it is the court that issued the existing custody and parenting‑time order, and because the minor child resides within the jurisdiction of this Court. See G.L. c. 215, § 6; G.L. c. 223, § 1.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: In determining the child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, emotional ties with each parent, the child’s school performance, the length of commute associated with parenting time, and the degree of stability and predictability in the child’s routine. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: By eliminating the Wednesday overnight and re‑structuring the Father’s parenting time to avoid long midweek drives on school nights, the child will enjoy more consistent sleep, improved school participation, and a more stable weekly routine, all of which are consistent with the statutory and common‑law emphasis on the child’s welfare. See G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 840–41; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. at 261–62.

*Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 74 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This material change affects the child’s day‑to‑day welfare, including her sleep, school performance, and overall well‑being, thereby satisfying the “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard for modification under Massachusetts law. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; *Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 74 Mass. App. Ct. 32 (2009).
*Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 74 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning:
The opinion excerpt is not Mazzone v. Mazzone at all; it is a sexually dangerous person civil commitment case involving Sanchez under G.L. c. 123A. It discusses statutory 60‑day trial deadlines and acquiescence to delay, not child custody, parenting plans, or any “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or c. 209C, § 20. Therefore, this text does not support the proposition about changes affecting a child’s day‑to‑day welfare as grounds for modification.

Because the supplied text does not match the cited family‑law case or the claimed legal standard, the proposition is not supported by this opinion excerpt.
*Mazzone v. Mazzone*, 74 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “With that factual setting as background, we begin our discussion by observing that, as a general matter, ‘the liberty interests at stake [in civil commitment proceedings] compel strict adherence to the time frames set forth in’ G. L. c. 123A. See Commonwealth v. Kennedy, 435 Mass. 527, 530-531 (2001)… The time frame of relevance here is set out in G. L. 123A, § 14(a).”

*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion in Pierce v. Pierce concerns modification of alimony obligations based on a payor spouse’s voluntary retirement and related financial circumstances. It does not address parenting time, child custody, or the effect of a parent’s change of residence on a child’s routine or school performance. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about material changes in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule.
*Pierce v. Pierce*, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.” Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not deal with modification of an existing parenting-time order based on a later change in a parent’s residence or its impact on a child’s routine or school performance. Instead, it concerns an initial custody determination under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), and explicitly declines to apply the “substantial change in circumstances” modification standard. The discussion of stability and continuity focuses on preserving an existing satisfactory arrangement, not on relocation as a material change warranting modification of parenting time.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody dispute focused on the impact of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings about that factor; it does not address relocation, parental moves, or changes in residence as a basis for modifying parenting time. There is no discussion of a change in a parent’s residence, disruption of a child’s daily routine due to a move, or school‑performance impacts as constituting a material change in circumstances. Accordingly, it does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: "As almost three years have gone by since the Probate Court issued its judgment and Vaughn is now almost fourteen years of age, it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference and for the judge to evaluate the success of the stipulated custody arrangement the parties have been living under in the interim." (The opinion elsewhere focuses on domestic violence, not relocation or residence changes.)

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns when a change in a parent’s residence constitutes a material change in circumstances justifying modification of a parenting‑time schedule. Yannas is a removal/custody case, not a modification case, and it does not discuss any ‘material change in circumstances’ standard or school performance/schedule stability as a trigger for modifying parenting time. Instead, it sets out the ‘real advantage’ best‑interests test for permitting a custodial parent to relocate with the children, so it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)….”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a custodial parent’s relocation can itself constitute the material and substantial change in circumstances required to modify an existing custody judgment. The Appeals Court holds that a request for relocation is distinct from a request for modification of custody and must be based on changes other than the move, and it finds no post‑divorce change warranting modification. It does not discuss a parent’s change of residence as a material change justifying modification of a *parenting‑time schedule* based on effects on the child’s daily routine or school performance; instead, it rejects using the move (and the temporary change ordered during litigation) as the basis for modifying physical custody at all.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The custody claim must be considered in light of established principles governing custody determinations.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a relocation (Rose’s move with Jill to Oregon and prospective move to Michigan) and its impact on the child, but only in the context of an initial custody determination under the best‑interests standard, not as a post‑judgment modification based on a ‘material change in circumstances.’ The court does not frame the residential move or its effects on the child’s routine or school performance as a ‘material change’ warranting modification of an existing parenting‑time schedule, nor does it describe such a rule as a consistent line of Massachusetts authority. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that, after the move to Oregon, Jill lived in four different residences in less than one year and had ‘no less than five different care providers,’ … In addition, Rose accepted a residency in Michigan, a State where she has no ties… The judge found that a move to Michigan would put Jill ‘in an unfamiliar environment with new caregivers and . . . medical providers’ while Rose worked ‘extraordinary long hours as a medical resident for the next four years’… By contrast, the judge found that Hunter ‘has a stable job … [that] provides flexibility…’”}

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation case applying the Yannas ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests framework under G.L. c. 208, § 30; it does not address modification of parenting‑time schedules based on a change of a parent’s residence as a material change in circumstances. The court’s discussion focuses on whether a proposed interstate move serves the custodial parent’s real advantage and the children’s best interests, not on whether such a change constitutes a ‘material change’ warranting modification of parenting time. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about material change and parenting‑time modification tied to residence changes and school stability.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “The removal from the Commonwealth of children of divorced parents is governed generally by G. L. c. 208, § 30… In determining whether cause for removal by the parent with primary physical custody has been shown under the statute, the judge must consider the custodial parent’s request under the familiar two-prong ‘real advantage’ test set forth in Yannas… ‘[T]he first consideration is whether there is a good reason for the move, a ‘real advantage.’ Second, if the real advantage test is satisfied, the judge must consider whether the move is in the best interests of the children.’”}

*Schelling v. Lindell*, 65 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*Schelling v. Lindell*, 65 Mass. App. Ct.case_name: Brown-Forman Corp. v. Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission
*Schelling v. Lindell*, 65 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is a commercial/administrative law case involving G. L. c. 138, § 25E and agency principles in the context of alcoholic beverage distribution. It does not involve family law, parenting time, child custody, or material changes in circumstances related to a parent’s residence or a child’s school performance. Therefore it cannot provide authority for the parenting‑time modification proposition stated.
*Schelling v. Lindell*, 65 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This appeal concerns a decision of the Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission (commission) in which it concluded on the evidence before it that the Brown-Forman Corporation (Brown-Forman) was required by G. L. c. 138, § 25E, to make regular sales of certain alcoholic beverage products to M.S. Walker, Inc. (Walker), a Massachusetts wholesaler of alcoholic beverages…”

*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that a change in a parent’s residence, especially one that substantially alters the child’s daily routine and affects school performance or stability, can constitute a material change in circumstances warranting modification of a parenting‑time schedule. See, e.g.:
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion in R.H. v. B.F. concerns an initial custody determination and the effect of domestic violence and battered‑woman’s syndrome on custody and legal custody, not modification of an existing parenting‑time schedule based on a change of a parent’s residence or impact on school or daily routine. The court never discusses relocation, change of residence, school performance, or material change in circumstances standards for modifying parenting time. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*R.H. v. B.F.*, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 29 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Custody orders and judgments are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child, and the statutes leave it to the trial judge to identify and weigh any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the specific dispute. ‘A Probate Court judge must settle custody in a manner that advances the best interests of the child.’ Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616 (1987)…”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.proposition: In determining the child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, emotional ties with each parent, the child’s school performance, the length of commute associated with parenting time, and the degree of stability and predictability in the child’s routine. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness, clear and convincing evidence, procedural protections, and the ability to draw adverse inferences from a parent’s failure to testify. It does not discuss or enumerate best-interest factors such as the child’s age and developmental needs, emotional ties with each parent, school performance, commute length, or stability/predictability of routine. Therefore, while it mentions the children’s need for a stable environment in a general sense, it does not provide authority for the specific multifactor best-interest analysis described in the proposition.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.relevant_excerpt: “In custody proceedings, the rights of the children to a stable and safe environment assume an importance at least equal to the interest of the parents in a fair proceeding. … A decision to remove children permanently from the home of their natural parents must be supported by clear and convincing evidence that the parents are currently unfit to care and provide for their children.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: In determining the child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, emotional ties with each parent, the child’s school performance, the length of commute associated with parenting time, and the degree of stability and predictability in the child’s routine. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion reiterates that the governing principle in custody cases is the welfare/best interests of the child and that all relevant factors must be weighed, but it does not identify or discuss specific factors such as age, developmental needs, school performance, commute length, or stability of routine. It only generically instructs the Probate Court on remand to consider the relative advantages of the parental environments and the length and effect of the child’s current placement. Thus, it supports the broad best‑interests standard, not the detailed list of factors in the proposition.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment and under the primary care of her father at his home and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related caselaw recognize that a child’s schedule and the impact of parental arrangements on the child’s education and health are central components of the best‑interests analysis. See *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983); *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.support_reasoning: This opinion is a care-and-protection/parental-unfitness case under G.L. c. 119, not a custody determination under G.L. c. 208, § 31. The court discusses parental fitness, state intervention standards, and procedural issues, but does not analyze a child’s schedule, schooling logistics, or the impact of parental arrangements on the child’s education and health as discrete, central factors in a best‑interests balancing. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific best‑interests formulation attributed to it in the proposition.
*Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Custody is not to be transferred from the natural parent simply because another prospective custodian is thought to be better qualified. A comparison of the advantage the prospective custodian may offer to the child with those that may be offered by the natural parents is inappropriate. … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … ‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’”

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31 and related caselaw recognize that a child’s schedule and the impact of parental arrangements on the child’s education and health are central components of the best‑interests analysis. See *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755 (1983); *Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection case under G.L. c. 119, not a custody case under G.L. c. 208, § 31, and it does not discuss that statute or explicitly frame best interests in terms of a child’s day‑to‑day schedule or the impact of parental arrangements on education and health. Its best‑interests discussion focuses instead on sibling relationships, placement within the natural family, and the dangers of separating siblings or severing family ties. While it certainly emphasizes children’s psychological and familial needs, it does not clearly stand for the more specific proposition claimed about schedules and educational/health impacts under c. 208, § 31.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’… The judge’s findings in this case are deficient in that he failed to address two issues: the importance of the sibling relationship, and whether placement of all three children with the paternal grandparents would be in the best interests of the children. The courts of this Commonwealth have recognized the importance of siblings’ being raised together.”
